title: STUDY THEME,  The Humanity of Jesus. Part 17
devotional:
As a man and as a son, meant that Jesus needed a continual, developing need of the presence and work of the Spirit in his life. We can fall into a trap of thinking that the work of the Spirit in my life is for those times when I am ‘serving God,’ or helping others. But no matter who or where we are, our need of the developing work of the Spirit in our hearts will never diminish or decrease. It is the work and ways of the Holy Spirit in us that distinguishes us as children of God.

We are told that the Spirit led Jesus into the wilderness. The word translated ‘sent’ in Mark 1:12 is a very weak translation. The word he uses for “Sent” is an extremely strong word, it literally means to drive out your enemies. In the LXX [the Greek translation of the Old Testament] the word is used in the context where an enemy who is frustrating or standing in the way of God fulfilling his purpose for his chosen people, is ‘cast out’ by God, so that God’s purposes may be fulfilled. See Exodus 23:30 Deuteronomy 33:27ff.

The word was mostly used in the New Testament in relation to casting out demons. The word expresses passion of God’s Ekballo, or God’s resistance to evil. God was sending his son into the wilderness with a strong passion so he could confront and unmask the evil one.

It is interesting to note that the word Luke uses to describe the Spirit leading Jesus into the wilderness. The word almost means the complete opposite to Ekballo, it has the idea to carry, to bring, and to keep.

Protected by passion

On the one hand we have the Spirit driving Jesus into the wilderness, as an expression of Gods passion against evil; and on the other had we have the keeping power of the Spirit leading Jesus. This is not a contradiction, nor is it even two opposites. God’s passion and God’s protection always go together.
prayer: Prayer, Father help me recognise that your leading on my life is not always the same.
